qa_pairs.question: What were the different types of coins and banknotes issued during the franga's circulation, and what specific actions were taken regarding the 1 franga banknote and 100 franga notes in 1939?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The franga was an obsolete unit of currency used in Albania, with coins issued in denominations of 1, 2, and 5 franga (silver) and 10, 20, 50, and 100 franga (gold) between 1926 and 1938. Fractional coins in lek and qindarka were also circulated during this period.<cite>[S3][S4]</cite></statement><statement>Banknotes included 1, 5, 20, and 100 franga notes, with the 1 franga note being recalled shortly after its 1926 issuance. In 1939, during the Italian occupation, 100 franga notes were overprinted to remove the image of King Zog I.<cite>[S5][S6][S7]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S1] Franga


# Franga



The **franga** [fɾaŋa] is an obsolete unit of currency, equal to 5 lek, used in the Albanian Republic and Albanian Kingdom under Zogu. [S2] Coins denominated in Franga were in use from 1926 until 1939. [S3] ## Coins

Between 1926 and 1938, 1, 2, and 5 franga coins were issued in silver (.835 fine for the two lower values, 900 fine for the five-franga coins), while 10, 20, 50, and 100 franga pieces were minted in gold (.900 fine). [S4] Fractional pieces denominated in lek and qindarka were also issued during the period. [S5] ## Banknotes

An undated series of banknotes was issued by the National Bank of Albania in 1926. [S6] It comprised 1, 5, 20, and 100 franga notes, the first of which was recalled shortly after being released into circulation. [S7] In 1939, during the Italian occupation, the 100 franga notes were overprinted to obscure the image of King Zog I.

qa_pairs.question: How did the metal composition of franga coins vary across denominations, and what additional currency units were issued alongside the franga?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The metal composition of franga coins varied by denomination, with 1, 2, and 5 franga coins issued in silver (0.835 fine for the two lower values and 0.900 fine for the five-franga coins), while 10, 20, 50, and 100 franga pieces were minted in gold (0.900 fine).<cite>[S3]</cite></statement> <statement>Fractional currency units such as lek and qindarka were also issued alongside the franga coins during the same period.<cite>[S4]</cite></statement>
